기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).explanation: This is the polite way to say 'is' in Korean. Attach 이에요 after a noun ending in a consonant, and 예요 after a noun ending in a vowel. It is used to identify or describe what something is.

drill.full_sentence_en: I am a Korean person.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).notes: Common mistake: using 예요 after a consonant. Remember — 학생이에요 (consonant ending), 의사예요 (vowel ending). This form is 해요체 (polite informal), which is the most commonly used speech level in everyday Korean.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).explanation: This is the negative form of the copula. Use 이 아니에요 after a consonant-ending noun and 가 아니에요 after a vowel-ending noun. It means 'is not' or 'am not'.

drill.full_sentence_en: I am not a teacher.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).notes: The particle 이/가 is required before 아니에요 — don't drop it. This is different from English where you just say 'is not'. Also note: 아니에요 never changes form; only the particle before it changes based on the noun.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).meaning: there is / there isn't; have / don't have
기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).explanation: 있어요 means 'there is' or 'I have', while 없어요 is its negative, meaning 'there isn't' or 'I don't have'. These are among the most frequently used words in Korean.

drill.full_sentence_en: There is milk in the refrigerator.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).notes: 있어요/없어요 use the subject particle 이/가, not the topic particle 은/는. A common beginner mistake is saying 있어요 when you mean the copula 이에요. 'I am a student' is 학생이에요 (not 학생이 있어요).

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).explanation: This is the standard polite present tense ending in Korean. If the last vowel of the verb stem is ㅏ or ㅗ, add -아요. For all other vowels, add -어요. 하다 verbs become 해요.

drill.full_sentence_en: I exercise every day.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).notes: The biggest challenge is vowel contraction. 가다 becomes 가요 (not 가아요), 마시다 becomes 마셔요 (시+어=셔). Memorize 하다→해요 as a special case. When in doubt, practice the most common verbs first until the pattern feels natural.

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).explanation: In Korean, you form a yes/no question simply by raising intonation at the end of a statement. The verb ending stays the same as the statement form. In writing, just add a question mark.

drill.full_sentence_en: Do you like this food?

기본 문장 (Basic Sentences).notes: Unlike English, Korean does NOT rearrange word order for questions — you don't need a 'do' or 'does'. The sentence structure is identical to a statement; only the intonation (spoken) or question mark (written) changes. Answers use 네 (yes) or 아니요 (no).

조사 (Particles).explanation: 은/는 marks the topic of the sentence — what you are talking about. Use 은 after a consonant and 는 after a vowel. It often translates loosely as 'as for...' and is used to introduce a topic or contrast two things.

examples.english: As for meat, I don't eat it.

drill.full_sentence_en: Today, the weather is good.

조사 (Particles).notes: 은/는 vs 이/가 is one of the hardest distinctions for beginners. As a rule of thumb: 은/는 is for known or contrasted information ('As for me...'), while 이/가 introduces new information or answers 'who/what'. Don't overthink it at first — exposure will build intuition.

조사 (Particles).explanation: 이/가 marks the grammatical subject of a sentence. Use 이 after a consonant and 가 after a vowel. It is used when introducing new information, emphasizing the subject, or in descriptive/existence sentences.

drill.full_sentence_en: I need water.

조사 (Particles).notes: 이/가 is commonly used with 있어요/없어요 and adjective sentences. After question words like 누구 (who) and 뭐 (what), always use 가: 누가 했어요? (Who did it?). Remember: 이 after consonant (물이), 가 after vowel (커피가).

조사 (Particles).explanation: 을/를 marks the direct object of a verb — the thing being acted upon. Use 을 after a consonant and 를 after a vowel. It answers the question 'what?' in relation to the verb.

drill.full_sentence_en: I watch a movie.

조사 (Particles).notes: In casual speech, 을/를 is often dropped: 밥 먹어요 instead of 밥을 먹어요. However, for beginners, practicing with the particle helps you internalize correct sentence structure. Use 을 after consonant (밥을), 를 after vowel (커피를).

조사 (Particles).meaning: at / in / on / to (location or time)
조사 (Particles).explanation: 에 marks a location where something exists or a destination you are going to. It is also used with time expressions. It does NOT change based on the preceding syllable.

drill.full_sentence_en: There are many books in the library.

조사 (Particles).notes: 에 vs 에서 is a key distinction. Use 에 for static location (existence) and destination (going to): 집에 있어요, 학교에 가요. Use 에서 for where an action takes place. Also, 에 is used for time: 아침에 (in the morning), 월요일에 (on Monday).

조사 (Particles).explanation: 에서 marks the location where an action takes place. Unlike 에 (static location/destination), 에서 is used when someone is actively doing something at that place. It can also mean 'from' a place.

drill.full_sentence_en: I drink coffee at the cafe.

조사 (Particles).notes: Remember this pair: 집에 있어요 (I am at home — existence uses 에) vs 집에서 일해요 (I work at home — action uses 에서). If the verb involves doing something, use 에서. If it's about being somewhere or going somewhere, use 에.

조사 (Particles).explanation: 도 means 'also' or 'too' and replaces the particles 은/는, 이/가, or 을/를 — it does not stack on top of them. Simply attach 도 directly to the noun.

drill.full_sentence_en: I also study Korean.

조사 (Particles).notes: A very common mistake is stacking particles: 저는도 (wrong) — it should be 저도. 도 replaces subject/topic/object markers entirely. Think of it as a substitute, not an addition.

조사 (Particles).explanation: 의 shows possession, similar to 's or 'of' in English. It connects two nouns where the first noun owns or is related to the second. It is pronounced as 에 in casual speech.

examples.english: I go to my friend's house.

drill.full_sentence_en: Whose bag is this?

조사 (Particles).notes: In everyday speech, 의 is often dropped, especially with pronouns: 내 (나의 shortened), 제 (저의 shortened). So 저의 가방 and 제 가방 both mean 'my bag'. You'll hear the pronunciation 에 more often than 의 in spoken Korean.

조사 (Particles).explanation: These all mean 'and' or 'with' when connecting nouns. 와 (after vowel) / 과 (after consonant) is more formal. 하고 is standard. (이)랑 is casual. They are largely interchangeable in meaning.

examples.english: I go together with a friend.

drill.full_sentence_en: I watch a movie with a friend.

조사 (Particles).notes: For beginners, 하고 is the safest choice because it doesn't change based on the preceding syllable. (이)랑 is very casual and common in spoken Korean. 와/과 appears more in writing and formal speech. All three are grammatically correct in most situations.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).explanation: To make past tense, add -았어요 if the last vowel of the stem is ㅏ or ㅗ, and -었어요 for all other vowels. 하다 verbs become 했어요. The same vowel harmony rules as present tense apply.

drill.full_sentence_en: I met a friend yesterday.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).notes: The vowel contraction rules are the same as present tense: 가다→갔어요, 오다→왔어요, 마시다→마셨어요. Common time words used with past tense: 어제 (yesterday), 지난주 (last week), 아까 (earlier). Don't forget: 하다→했어요 is irregular and must be memorized.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).explanation: This expresses future plans or intentions. Add -을 거예요 after a consonant-ending stem and -ㄹ 거예요 after a vowel-ending stem. It is the most common way to talk about the future in casual polite speech.

examples.english: I will go to school tomorrow.
I will rest on the weekend.
I will meet a friend in the evening.

drill.full_sentence_en: What will you do on the weekend?

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).notes: A common mistake is forgetting the space: it's 갈 거예요 (three parts: stem+ㄹ, 거, 예요). Don't confuse this with -(으)ㄹ게요, which is a promise/commitment ('I will do it for you'). -을/ㄹ 거예요 is a neutral statement about a future plan.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).explanation: This form expresses an action that is currently in progress, similar to English '-ing'. Attach -고 있어요 directly to the verb stem. It works with all verbs without any stem changes.

examples.english: I am waiting for a friend.

drill.full_sentence_en: I am reading a book now.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).notes: Unlike English, Korean doesn't require the progressive form as often. 지금 공부해요 and 지금 공부하고 있어요 are both natural for 'I'm studying now'. The progressive form emphasizes that the action is happening right at this moment. This pattern is easy because there are no stem changes — just add -고 있어요.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).explanation: Attach -고 싶어요 to a verb stem to express a desire to do something. It means 'I want to (verb)'. It is only used for your own desires; for third person, use -고 싶어해요.

examples.english: I want to go to Korea.

drill.full_sentence_en: I want to eat delicious food.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).notes: For past desire ('wanted to'), say -고 싶었어요. For questions, just raise intonation: 뭐 먹고 싶어요? (What do you want to eat?). Remember: -고 싶어요 is only for 'I want to'. For 'he/she wants to', use -고 싶어해요.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).explanation: This is a polite way to tell someone not to do something. Attach -지 마세요 directly to the verb stem. It is the negative imperative in polite form.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please don't smoke here.

동사 시제 (Verb Tenses).notes: 걱정하지 마세요 (Don't worry) is one of the most common expressions in Korean. Don't confuse this with -지 않아요 (negative statement) — 마세요 is a command/request not to do something, while 않아요 is describing that something doesn't happen.

연결 (Connectors).explanation: Use -고 to connect two actions or descriptions in sequence, meaning 'and' or 'and then'. Attach it directly to the verb stem. There is no stem change needed, making it one of the easiest connectors.

examples.english: I eat breakfast and go to school.
This room is big and bright.

drill.full_sentence_en: I drink coffee and work.

연결 (Connectors).notes: -고 simply lists or sequences actions without implying cause/effect. For 'because', use -아/어서 or -(으)니까 instead. The tense is only marked on the final verb: 먹고 갔어요 (ate and went), not 먹었고 갔어요.

연결 (Connectors).explanation: Use -지만 to contrast two clauses, meaning 'but' or 'however'. Attach it directly to the verb or adjective stem. No stem changes are needed.

examples.english: I'm tired but I have to study.

drill.full_sentence_en: The weather is cold but I will take a walk.

연결 (Connectors).notes: -지만 is the simplest way to say 'but' in Korean and is always safe to use. There is a more formal version, -(으)나, and a spoken version, -는데, but -지만 is the best starting point for beginners.

연결 (Connectors).explanation: This connector has two uses: expressing a reason ('because') or a sequential action ('and then'). The same vowel harmony rules apply: -아서 after ㅏ/ㅗ stems, -어서 after others, 하다 becomes 해서.

examples.english: Because my stomach hurt, I went to the hospital.
Nice to meet you. (Having met you, I'm glad.)
Because it rained, I took an umbrella.

drill.full_sentence_en: Because I was tired, I slept early.

연결 (Connectors).notes: Important rule: you cannot use past tense (-았/었-) in the -아/어서 clause. Say 배가 아파서 (not 배가 아팠어서). The tense is only marked on the final verb. Also, -아/어서 cannot be used with imperative or suggestive endings — use -(으)니까 instead.

연결 (Connectors).explanation: This also means 'because' but is stronger and more subjective than -아/어서. Use -으니까 after a consonant stem and -니까 after a vowel stem. Unlike -아/어서, it CAN be used with commands and suggestions.

examples.english: Because there's no time, please go quickly.
It's delicious, so please eat a lot.
Because it's raining, please take an umbrella.

drill.full_sentence_en: Because the weather is nice, let's take a walk.

연결 (Connectors).notes: Key difference: -아/어서 states an objective reason, while -(으)니까 gives a personal or subjective reason and can be used with commands (-세요) and suggestions (-(으)ㄹ까요?). If the sentence ends with 'please do X', use -(으)니까 for the reason.

연결 (Connectors).explanation: This expresses a condition ('if') or a general timing ('when'). Use -으면 after a consonant-ending stem and -면 after a vowel-ending stem. It is one of the most useful grammar patterns in Korean.

examples.english: If you have time, let's go together.
If it rains, I will stay home.
If you go to Korea, what do you want to do?

drill.full_sentence_en: If you are hungry, please eat this.

연결 (Connectors).notes: -(으)면 is neutral and versatile. For hypothetical situations, you can add 만약 at the start: 만약 시간이 있으면... (If by chance you have time...). A common fixed expression: 괜찮으면 (if it's okay). Note: 고프다 ends in a vowel stem, so it's 고프면 (not 고프으면).

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).explanation: These are demonstrative words placed before nouns. 이 means 'this' (near the speaker), 그 means 'that' (near the listener or previously mentioned), and 저 means 'that over there' (far from both). They are always followed by a noun.

examples.english: That building over there is the school.

drill.full_sentence_en: This bag is mine.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).notes: Don't confuse 이/그/저 (before nouns) with 이것/그것/저것 (standalone pronouns meaning 'this thing/that thing'). 그 is also used for things previously mentioned in conversation, similar to 'the' in English. You'll hear 이거/그거/저거 as casual short forms of 이것/그것/저것.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).explanation: Korean has two number systems: native Korean (하나, 둘, 셋...) and Sino-Korean (일, 이, 삼...). Counters are special words attached to numbers to count specific things. Native Korean numbers are used with most counters for everyday objects.

examples.english: Please give me two cups of coffee.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please give me one glass of water.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).notes: Key counters to memorize: 개 (general objects), 명/사람 (people), 잔 (cups/glasses), 마리 (animals), 권 (books), 벌 (clothing). Native Korean numbers 1-4 change form before counters: 하나→한, 둘→두, 셋→세, 넷→네. Sino-Korean numbers are used for dates, money, phone numbers, and minutes.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).explanation: Place 안 directly before the verb to negate it, meaning 'not' or 'don't'. This is the simplest way to make negative sentences in Korean. For 하다 compound verbs, 안 goes between the noun and 하다.

drill.full_sentence_en: I don't eat breakfast.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).notes: For 하다 verbs, 안 goes before 하다, not before the whole word: 공부 안 해요 (not 안 공부해요). 안 expresses a choice not to do something, while 못 expresses inability. There is also a longer form -지 않아요 which has the same meaning.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).explanation: Place 못 before a verb to express inability or impossibility. It means 'cannot' or 'is unable to'. Like 안, for 하다 compound verbs, 못 goes between the noun and 하다.

drill.full_sentence_en: I can't eat spicy food.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).notes: 못 implies inability (can't because of circumstances or lack of skill), while 안 implies choice (don't/won't). Compare: 안 가요 (I'm choosing not to go) vs 못 가요 (I can't go). 못 is not used with adjectives — you can't say 못 예뻐요; use 안 예뻐요 instead.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).explanation: This is the long-form negation, equivalent to 안 + verb. Attach -지 않아요 to the verb stem. It sounds slightly more formal or emphatic than the short form 안.

drill.full_sentence_en: This food is not spicy.

수량 & 지시 (Quantity & Demonstratives).notes: 안 먹어요 and 먹지 않아요 mean the same thing. The -지 않아요 form is preferred in writing and can sound more deliberate. For past tense, change 않아요 to 않았어요: 가지 않았어요 (didn't go). This form is also easier with long 하다 compound verbs: 운동하지 않아요 (clearer than 운동을 안 해요).

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).explanation: This is used to politely ask someone to do something for you. Attach the -아/어 form of the verb followed by 주세요. It adds a nuance of doing the action as a favor or service.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please open the door (for me).

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).notes: This is different from a plain command (-(으)세요). 열어 주세요 implies 'open it for me', while 여세요 is simply 'open it'. Use -아/어 주세요 when asking for a favor — it sounds softer and more polite. Very useful in restaurants, shops, and daily requests.

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).explanation: This ending is used for polite commands and instructions, and also as an honorific present tense for someone you respect. Use -으세요 after consonant stems and -세요 after vowel stems.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please eat slowly. (polite/honorific)

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).notes: -(으)세요 has two uses: giving polite instructions (앉으세요 = please sit) and talking about someone you respect (선생님이 오세요 = the teacher comes). Some verbs have special honorific forms: 먹다→드시다 (드세요), 자다→주무시다 (주무세요), 있다→계시다 (계세요).

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).meaning: May I? / Is it okay to?
요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).explanation: Use this to ask or give permission. Attach -아/어도 돼요 to the verb stem. As a question it means 'May I?' or 'Is it okay if I?'. As a statement, 돼요 confirms permission and 안 돼요 denies it.

drill.full_sentence_en: May I eat this?

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).notes: To say 'you can't / you may not', use -아/어도 안 돼요 or -(으)면 안 돼요: 여기서 담배를 피우면 안 돼요 (You can't smoke here). Note the spelling: 돼요 (O), not 되요 (X). This is one of the most common spelling mistakes even native Korean speakers make.

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).explanation: This expresses ability or possibility. Use -을 수 있어요 after a consonant-ending stem and -ㄹ 수 있어요 after a vowel-ending stem. Replace 있어요 with 없어요 for 'cannot'.

drill.full_sentence_en: I can play the piano.

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).notes: This is more formal than 못: 못 해요 and 할 수 없어요 both mean 'can't do it', but the latter sounds more polished. The 수 in this pattern is a bound noun meaning 'way/means', so literally it means 'the way to do it exists/doesn't exist'. Always keep a space: 할 수 있어요 (not 할수있어요).

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).explanation: This expresses obligation or necessity. Attach -아/어야 해요 to the verb stem using the standard vowel harmony rules. It translates as 'must', 'have to', or 'should'.

examples.english: I have to wake up early tomorrow.

drill.full_sentence_en: I have to depart now.

요청 & 제안 (Requests & Suggestions).notes: For 'don't have to', use -지 않아도 돼요: 가지 않아도 돼요 (You don't have to go). Note this is different from -지 마세요 (don't do it — a prohibition). 해야 해요 has two 해's in a row, which feels odd at first but is correct: 숙제를 해야 해요 (I have to do homework).

묘사 (Description).explanation: Korean uses verb/adjective endings to modify nouns directly (like relative clauses). For adjectives: add -(으)ㄴ. For present-tense verbs: add -는. For past-tense verbs: add -(으)ㄴ. This is how Korean says 'the book I read' or 'a big house'.

examples.english: The book I'm reading now is interesting.
The person I met yesterday is a teacher.

drill.full_sentence_en: I want to eat delicious food.

묘사 (Description).notes: This is one of the trickier grammar points for beginners. The key rule: adjectives use -(으)ㄴ (큰 집 = big house, 작은 가방 = small bag), action verbs use -는 for present (먹는 사람 = person who eats). Note: 있다/없다 use -는 (맛있는, 재미없는), not -(으)ㄴ.

묘사 (Description).explanation: Attach 보다 after a noun to create a comparison, meaning 'more than'. The thing being compared to gets 보다, and the sentence often includes 더 (more) before the adjective, though 더 is optional.

examples.english: I like winter more than summer.
Coffee is more expensive than tea.

drill.full_sentence_en: Today is colder than yesterday.

묘사 (Description).notes: Word order is flexible. Both 여름보다 겨울이 좋아요 and 겨울이 여름보다 좋아요 are correct and natural. 더 (more) is often included but not required — Korean speakers frequently drop it since 보다 already implies comparison. Don't add 더 with 제일/가장 (superlative).

묘사 (Description).explanation: Place 제일 or 가장 before an adjective or verb to express the superlative ('the most'). 제일 is slightly more casual and common in speech, while 가장 is more neutral. They are interchangeable.

examples.korean: 한국 음식 중에서 비빔밥이 제일 좋아요.
examples.english: Among Korean food, I like bibimbap the most.
This bag is the most expensive.

drill.full_sentence: 우리 반에서 민수가 제일 키가 커요.
drill.full_sentence_en: In our class, Minsu is the tallest.

묘사 (Description).notes: A very useful expression: 제일 좋아하는 _____ (favorite _____). For example: 제일 좋아하는 음식 (favorite food). Don't use 더 (more) with 제일/가장 — it would be redundant. Use 중에서 (among) to specify the group: 친구 중에서 (among friends).

묘사 (Description).explanation: Attach 처럼 or 같이 after a noun to say 'like' or 'similar to'. Both are largely interchangeable, though 처럼 is more common in writing and 같이 is more common in casual speech.

examples.english: She is pretty like an actress.

drill.full_sentence_en: That person is kind like an angel.

묘사 (Description).notes: 같이 has two meanings: 'like/similar to' (noun + 같이) and 'together' (같이 가요 = let's go together). Context makes the meaning clear. 처럼 only means 'like/similar to', so it's unambiguous. A common expression: 나처럼 해 봐요 (Try doing it like me).

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).explanation: Use this to make suggestions or ask someone's opinion about doing something together. Add -을까요 after a consonant-ending stem and -ㄹ까요 after a vowel-ending stem. It can mean 'shall we?' or 'shall I?'.

drill.full_sentence_en: Shall we drink coffee?

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).notes: This is softer and more polite than a direct suggestion. It invites the other person's input. For responding: 네, 좋아요! (Yes, sounds good!) or 아니요, 괜찮아요 (No, it's okay). Don't confuse this with -(으)ㄹ 거예요 (future tense statement) — -(으)ㄹ까요 is always a question.

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).explanation: This expresses purpose of movement — going or coming somewhere to do something. Use -으러 after consonant stems and -러 after vowel stems, followed by 가다 (go) or 오다 (come).

examples.english: I go to a restaurant to eat.
I came to Korea to learn Korean.
I go to a cafe to meet a friend.

drill.full_sentence_en: I go to the park to exercise.

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).notes: This pattern can ONLY be used with movement verbs (가다, 오다, 다니다, etc.). You cannot say 먹으러 공부해요 (X) — the second verb must be about going or coming. For general purpose without movement, use -(으)려고: 건강하려고 운동해요 (I exercise in order to be healthy).

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).explanation: This expresses trying or experiencing something. Attach the -아/어 form of the verb followed by 보다 (to see). It literally means 'do and see', conveying the idea of trying something out.

examples.english: May I try on these clothes?
I tried watching a Korean drama.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please try this cake.

유용한 표현 (Useful Expressions).notes: 한번 (once) is often added for emphasis: 한번 해 보세요 (Give it a try). For past tense ('I have tried'), use -아/어 봤어요: 한국에 가 봤어요 (I have been to Korea / I tried going to Korea). This pattern is very common and natural in everyday Korean — use it freely when suggesting someone try something.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).explanation: Attach -기 전에 to a verb stem to express 'before doing' something. The verb before 전에 is always in its base stem form (no tense marking). 전에 literally means 'before', and -기 turns the verb into a noun clause.

examples.english: I brush my teeth before sleeping.
I wash my hands before eating.

drill.full_sentence_en: Please check before departing.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).notes: Never conjugate the verb before -기 전에. It is always verb stem + 기 전에, regardless of tense. The tense of the whole sentence is shown on the final verb only. Compare: 먹기 전에 (before eating) vs 먹은 후에 (after eating).

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).explanation: These two patterns both express 'after doing' something. -(으)ㄴ 후에 attaches the past modifier to 후에 ('after'), while -고 나서 uses the connector -고 plus 나서 ('after coming out of'). Both are interchangeable in most situations.

examples.english: I take a walk after eating lunch.
I got a job after graduating.

drill.full_sentence_en: I play after doing homework.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).notes: With -(으)ㄴ 후에, the verb takes the past modifier form: 먹다→먹은, 하다→한, 가다→간. With -고 나서, simply attach to the verb stem: 먹고 나서, 하고 나서. -고 나서 can be shortened to just -고 나면 when the meaning is clear from context.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).explanation: 동안 means 'during' or 'for a period of'. It can follow a noun (방학 동안 — during vacation) or a verb clause in the -는 form (기다리는 동안 — while waiting). It emphasizes the duration of the time span.

examples.english: I read a book while waiting.

drill.full_sentence_en: I exercised for three hours.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).notes: When used with a verb, the verb takes the present tense modifier -는: 먹는 동안 (while eating), 자는 동안 (while sleeping). With a noun expressing a time period, just add 동안 directly: 일주일 동안 (for one week), 한 달 동안 (for one month).

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).explanation: 때 means 'time' or 'when'. It can follow a noun (어릴 때 — when young) or a verb in modifier form. For present/habitual actions use -(으)ㄹ 때, and for past situations use the appropriate modifier. It marks the time context of an action.

examples.english: When I was young, I lived in Korea.
Contact me when you have time.
A phone call came when I was eating.

drill.full_sentence_en: I listen to music when I'm sad.

시간 표현 (Time Expressions).notes: The modifier form before 때 depends on the word type: adjectives use -(으)ㄹ 때 for general situations (바쁠 때 — when busy), verbs use -(으)ㄹ 때 for uncompleted or habitual actions (갈 때 — when going). Nouns use 때 directly: 학생 때 (when I was a student).

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).explanation: This pattern gives a reason or cause. -기 turns the verb into a noun clause, and 때문에 means 'because of'. It is more formal and explicit than -아/어서 or -(으)니까. Nouns can directly attach to 때문에 without -기.

examples.english: I brought an umbrella because it is raining.
I study hard because there is an exam.
I stayed home because of the weather.

drill.full_sentence_en: I couldn't go because I was busy.

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).notes: Compare the three 'because' patterns: -아/어서 (natural cause, no imperative after), -(으)니까 (subjective reason, can use imperative/suggestion after), -기 때문에 (formal/explicit, works anywhere). With nouns, drop -기: 날씨 때문에 (because of the weather), 일 때문에 (because of work).

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).explanation: Attach -(으)려고 to a verb stem to express intention or purpose — 'in order to do' something. Use -려고 after vowel-ending stems and -으려고 after consonant-ending stems. The subject of both clauses must be the same person.

examples.english: I came to Korea to learn Korean.
I went to the department store to buy a gift.
I exercise every day to become healthy.

drill.full_sentence_en: I went to the cafe to meet a friend.

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).notes: Both -(으)려고 and -(으)러 express purpose, but -(으)러 can only be used with movement verbs like 가다/오다 (가다→배우러 가다). -(으)려고 is more versatile and works with any verb in the second clause. Also note: -(으)려고 하다 means 'to be planning/intending to'.

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).meaning: for the purpose of / in order to
이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).explanation: This pattern expresses purpose more formally than -(으)려고. -기 turns the verb into a noun, and 위해(서) means 'for the sake of'. It is commonly used in writing, speeches, and formal situations. 서 is optional.

examples.english: I studied hard in order to pass the exam.
I work part-time in order to save money.

drill.full_sentence_en: I practice every day in order to be good at Korean.

이유 & 목적 (Reasons & Purpose).notes: 위해(서) can also follow nouns directly without -기: 가족을 위해서 (for the family), 미래를 위해서 (for the future). Compared to -(으)려고, -기 위해(서) sounds more deliberate and formal. In casual speech, -(으)려고 is more natural.

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).meaning: honorific infix (to show respect for the subject)
존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).explanation: Insert -(으)시- into a verb to show respect toward the person performing the action. Use -시- after vowel-ending stems and -으시- after consonant-ending stems. This is essential in Korean when talking about or to someone you respect.

drill.full_sentence_en: The boss went to the meeting room.

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).notes: Some verbs have special honorific forms that replace the verb entirely: 먹다→드시다, 자다→주무시다, 있다→계시다, 말하다→말씀하시다. Never use -(으)시- about yourself — it is only for people you are elevating. Using 저는 가셨어요 about yourself would be a social error.

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).meaning: to give (to a respected person) / to receive from a respected person
존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).explanation: 드리다 is the humble form of 주다, used when you give something to a respected person. 주시다 adds the honorific -(으)시- to 주다, used when a respected person gives something. These replace 주다 in polite contexts.

examples.english: I gave a gift to the teacher.
I want to give my parents a letter.

drill.full_sentence_en: I gave flowers to my mother.

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).notes: Use 께 instead of 에게 when the recipient is a respected person: 선생님께 (to the teacher), 부모님께 (to the parents). The pattern -아/어 드리다 means 'to do something for a respected person': 도와 드리다 (to help someone respected), 만들어 드리다 (to make for someone respected).

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).explanation: Korean has special honorific nouns used when referring to things belonging to or associated with respected people. 말씀 replaces 말 (words/speech), 진지 replaces 밥 (meal/rice), and 댁 replaces 집 (house/home). Using these shows proper respect.

examples.english: Listen well to the teacher's words.

drill.full_sentence_en: Grandmother, please eat your meal.

존댓말 & 높임말 (Honorifics).notes: Other important honorific noun pairs: 나이→연세 (age), 이름→성함 (name), 생일→생신 (birthday), 아프다→편찮으시다 (to be sick). 말씀하다 is used both as humble ('I humbly say') and honorific ('the respected person says') depending on context. These pairs are essential for polite Korean.

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).explanation: This pattern expresses a guess or soft prediction about the future. -(으)ㄹ is the future modifier, 것 means 'thing', and 같아요 means 'seems like'. It softens statements and makes them sound less certain, which is very common in Korean conversation.

examples.english: I think it will rain tomorrow.
I think this movie will be fun.
I think it will take some time.

drill.full_sentence_en: I think it will snow on the weekend.

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).notes: This is one of the most useful patterns in Korean for softening statements. Koreans often prefer indirect expressions, so instead of 'it will rain', saying '비가 올 것 같아요' (it seems like it will rain) sounds more natural and polite. Use it freely when expressing opinions or predictions.

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).explanation: The infix -겠- expresses either the speaker's intention ('I will do') or a conjecture about a situation ('it would be / it must be'). When used in first person, it shows determination. When used about others or situations, it shows inference or supposition.

examples.english: That must be delicious! / That looks delicious!
It will probably be cold tomorrow.

drill.full_sentence_en: This cake must be really delicious!

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).notes: Compare -겠- and -(으)ㄹ 거예요: both can express future, but -겠- sounds more formal and decisive for intention (제가 하겠습니다 — 'I shall do it'), while -(으)ㄹ 거예요 is more casual and plan-based. For conjecture, 맛있겠다 is a reaction to something you see, while 맛있을 거예요 is a general prediction.

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).explanation: This pattern expresses a guess or impression about present or past situations. For verbs, use -는 것 같아요 (present) or -(으)ㄴ 것 같아요 (past). For adjectives, use -(으)ㄴ 것 같아요 (present). It is softer than stating something as fact.

examples.korean: 지금 밖에 비가 오는 것 같아요.
examples.english: It seems like it's raining outside now.

examples.korean: 그 사람이 한국 사람인 것 같아요.
examples.english: That person seems to be Korean.
It seems like they already arrived.

drill.prompt: 민수 씨가 지금 자_____ 것 같아요.
drill.full_sentence: 민수 씨가 지금 자는 것 같아요.
drill.full_sentence_en: It seems like Minsu is sleeping now.

추측 & 의견 (Guessing & Opinion).notes: The modifier form changes the time reference: -는 것 같아요 = seems like (now), -(으)ㄴ 것 같아요 = seems like (already happened), -(으)ㄹ 것 같아요 = seems like (will happen). This three-way distinction is one of the most important grammar concepts for intermediate Korean.

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).explanation: This pattern expresses whether someone has or has not experienced something. -(으)ㄴ is the past modifier, 적 means 'occasion/instance', and 있다/없다 indicates existence or lack of that experience. It is equivalent to 'have you ever...' in English.

examples.english: I have been to Korea before.

drill.full_sentence_en: Have you ever made kimchi?

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).notes: The verb before 적 always takes the past modifier form -(으)ㄴ because you are describing a completed experience: 먹다→먹은 적, 가다→간 적, 보다→본 적. A common mistake is using the present modifier -는: 먹는 적 is incorrect. To answer: 네, 있어요 (yes, I have) / 아니요, 없어요 (no, I haven't).

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).explanation: Attach -마다 to a noun to mean 'every' or 'each'. It indicates that something applies to all instances without exception. It can follow time nouns (날마다 — every day), place nouns (나라마다 — every country), or people (사람마다 — every person).

examples.english: Every country has a different culture.

drill.full_sentence_en: I eat with family every evening.

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).notes: 마다 and 매- are similar: 날마다 = 매일 (every day), but 마다 is more versatile because it attaches to any noun. You cannot say 매사람 but you can say 사람마다. 마다 emphasizes 'each and every one', while 매- is limited to time-related words like 매주 (every week), 매달 (every month), 매년 (every year).

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).explanation: This combines the time expression 때 with 마다 to mean 'every time' or 'whenever' something happens. The verb takes the future/general modifier -(으)ㄹ before 때마다. It expresses a habitual or repeated connection between two events.

examples.korean: 한국 노래를 들을 때마다 기분이 좋아요.
examples.english: Every time I listen to Korean songs, I feel good.

examples.korean: 비가 올 때마다 집에 있고 싶어요.
examples.english: Whenever it rains, I want to stay home.
I smile every time I see this photo.

drill.full_sentence_en: Every time I exercise, I listen to music.

경험 & 빈도 (Experience & Frequency).notes: The modifier before 때마다 is -(으)ㄹ, the same future/general form used with 때 alone. This pattern emphasizes repetition — every single time without exception. For a softer, less absolute feel, you can use -(으)ㄹ 때 without 마다: 비가 올 때 (when it rains) vs 비가 올 때마다 (every single time it rains).

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).meaning: to become / to get (change of state)
변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).explanation: Attach -아/어지다 to an adjective stem to express a change of state — 'to become' that quality. The same vowel harmony rules as -아/어요 apply: ㅏ/ㅗ take -아지다, others take -어지다. This is how Korean expresses gradual or resulting changes.

drill.full_sentence_en: The days are getting colder.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).notes: This pattern primarily attaches to adjectives, not action verbs. For action verbs, use passive forms or -게 되다 instead. Common examples: 예쁘다→예뻐지다 (become pretty), 크다→커지다 (become big), 좋다→좋아지다 (become good). The change can be gradual (점점 — gradually) or sudden.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).meaning: to come to / to end up (unplanned result)
변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).explanation: Attach -게 to a verb or adjective stem, then add 되다 to express an unplanned or natural result — 'to come to do' or 'to end up doing'. It suggests the change happened due to circumstances rather than the speaker's deliberate choice.

examples.english: I ended up working at a Korean company.
I finally came to know / found out.

drill.full_sentence_en: I ended up living in Seoul.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).notes: Compare -게 되다 with -아/어지다: both express change, but -게 되다 works with action verbs and emphasizes circumstantial change (I ended up doing X), while -아/어지다 works with adjectives and emphasizes the resulting state (it became X). 알게 되다 (come to know) is one of the most common uses of this pattern.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).explanation: This pattern expresses how much time has passed since an event. Use the past modifier -(으)ㄴ + 지, then a time duration, followed by 되다 or 지나다 (to pass). It is the Korean equivalent of 'it has been X since...'.

examples.korean: 한국에 온 지 일 년 됐어요.
examples.english: It has been one year since I came to Korea.

examples.korean: 한국어를 배운 지 삼 개월 됐어요.
examples.english: It has been three months since I started learning Korean.

examples.korean: 밥을 먹은 지 세 시간 지났어요.
examples.english: It has been three hours since I ate.

drill.prompt: 이 회사에서 일한 _____ 오 년 됐어요.
drill.full_sentence: 이 회사에서 일한 지 오 년 됐어요.
drill.full_sentence_en: It has been five years since I started working at this company.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).notes: The verb before 지 always takes the past modifier -(으)ㄴ: 오다→온 지, 먹다→먹은 지, 시작하다→시작한 지. The time duration comes between 지 and 되다: 온 지 2년 됐어요. A common mistake is confusing this with -동안, which marks duration of an ongoing action, not elapsed time since an event.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).explanation: This pattern expresses a decision or agreement to do something. -기 turns the verb into a noun clause, -로 indicates the direction of the decision, and 하다 means 'to do'. It is commonly used for both personal decisions and group agreements.

examples.english: I decided to go to Korea next year.
I decided to exercise every day.
My friend and I decided to travel together.

drill.full_sentence_en: I decided to go on a diet.

변화 & 결과 (Change & Result).notes: This pattern almost always appears in the past tense (하기로 했어요) because you are reporting a decision already made. For promises or agreements with others, it implies a commitment: 만나기로 했어요 (we agreed to meet). Breaking such a decision is 약속을 어기다 (to break a promise). Compare with -(으)려고 하다 (intending to) which is softer and less committed.
